issues.text: Whether the High Court failed to discharge its duty under s.374 CrPC to independently consider the entire evidence before confirming the death sentences?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sawhney who has addressed the principal argument before us on behalf of the appellants, has urged that the High Court has failed in discharging its duty properly when it dealt with the appeals brought before it by the appellants and decided to confirm the sentences of death impose on 10 of the accused persons.

issues.text: Whether the failure to examine three material witnesses (Ram Prasad, Mansa Ram, Rani Dulhan) or summon them under s.540 CrPC vitiates the trial?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sawhney strongly relied on the fact that the High Court has not considered one important point in favour of the defence, and that is in relation to the failure of the prosecution to tender three material witnesses whose names had been shown in the witness-list...

issues.text: Whether evidence of partisan or interested witnesses belonging to the victims' faction should be discarded?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sawhney has then argued that where witnesses giving evidence in a murder trial like the present are shown to belong to the faction of victims, their evidence should not be accepted, because they are prone to involve falsely members...

issues.text: Whether the uniform pattern of evidence without assigning specific overt acts to individual assailants is unreliable?

anchor.surface_text: Then it is urged that the evidence given by the witnesses conforms to the same uniform pattern and since no specific part is assigned to all the assailants, that evidence should not have been accepted.

issues.text: Whether the High Court's test of requiring at least four consistent witnesses for conviction is mechanical and invalid?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sawhney also urged that the test applied by the High Court in convicting the appellants is mechanical. He argues that under the Indian Evidence Act, trustworthy evidence given by a single witness would be enough...

issues.text: Whether mere presence in the assembly makes a person a member of unlawful assembly, or overt act required (re Baladin case, ss.141,142 IPC)?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sawhney then attempted to argue that the High Court failed to give effect to the principles enunciated by this Court in the case of Baladin v. State of Uttar Pradesh. In that case... mere presence in an assembly does not make a person... unless... s.142 I.P.C.

issues.text: Whether death sentence can be imposed under s.302/149 IPC on members of unlawful assembly without proof of personal commission of murder?

anchor.surface_text: That leaves one question still to be considered and that has relation to the sentence of death imposed on 10 persons. Mr. Sawhney argues that in confirming the sentences of death... the High Court has adopted a mechanical rule.

issues.text: Whether points not raised before High Court can be urged in Supreme Court appeal under Art.136 in death sentence cases?

anchor.surface_text: It may be conceded that if a point of fact which plainly arises on the record, or a point of law which is relevant and material... was urged before the trial Court and... not repeated before the High Court, it may... be permissible... under Art. 136 of the Constitution...

holdings.text: The High Court properly discharged its duty under s.374 CrPC by independently considering the evidence before confirming the death sentences.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the manner in which the High Court has dealt with the appeals brought before it, we are not prepared to hold that the general criticism made by Mr. Sawhney against the judgment of the High Court can be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court judgment shows careful examination of arguments, evidence, infirmities, and adoption of safe test of four consistent witnesses.

holdings.text: Failure to examine three material witnesses does not vitiate the trial; prosecution not bound to tender won-over or terrorized witnesses, and trial court properly refused summons under s.540 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: we are satisfied that there is no substance in the contention which Mr. Sawhney seeks to raise before us. It is not unknown that where serious offences like the present are committed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Witnesses won over or unable; trial court examined and found not essential; unchallenged finding of fact.

holdings.text: Partisan or interested witness evidence should not be discarded mechanically but scrutinized carefully for discrepancies, genuineness, and probability.

anchor.surface_text: But it would, we think, be unreasonable to contend that evidence given by witnesses should be discarded only on the ground that it is evidence of partisan or interested witnesses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common in faction cases; mechanical rejection leads to failure of justice; no hard and fast rule.

holdings.text: Uniform pattern of evidence without specific overt acts to individuals is reliable in unlawful assembly cases with common object.

anchor.surface_text: This criticism again is not well-founded. Where a crowd of assailants who are members of an unlawful assembly proceed to commit an offence of murder

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not always possible to specify each role; not all need to assault; sift evidence carefully.

holdings.text: High Court's test of requiring at least four consistent witnesses is a useful, rational safeguard, not mechanical or invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we do not think that any grievance can be made by the appellants against the adoption of this test. If at all the prosecution may be entitled to say

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quality matters most, but number supports consistency in cases with many offenders/victims.

holdings.text: Mere presence does not make one a member of unlawful assembly, but armed members sharing common object under ss.141/142 IPC are liable under s.149 without overt act; Baladin distinguished.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Baladin involved passive witnesses; here all armed faction with common object to exterminate.

holdings.text: Points of fact or law plainly arising on record, urged at trial but not at High Court, can be raised in Supreme Court under Art.136 in death sentence cases.

anchor.surface_text: It may be conceded that if a point of fact which plainly arises on the record, or a point of law which is relevant and material and can be argued without any further evidence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Solemnity of death cases justifies flexibility; no hard and fast rule.

holdings.text: Death sentence under s.302/149 IPC permissible without personal commission of murder if facts warrant extreme penalty, given gruesome nature and need to suppress.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Vicarious liability under s.149; armed group intent to exterminate; discretion properly exercised.

holdings.text: Sentences of death modified to life imprisonment for three young accused (Nos. 9,11,16) who joined under pressure of elders.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the circumstances under which the unlawful assembly came to be formed, we are satisfied that these young men must have joined the unlawful assembly

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ages 18,23,24; sons influenced by fathers; ends of justice met by life terms.

holdings.text: Convictions and sentences confirmed except for modification in three cases.
holdings.reasoning_summary: All arguments rejected; evidence supports findings of guilt under s.302/149 etc.

precedents.citation: Jumman Ors. v. The State of Punjab

anchor.surface_text: Jumman Ors. v. The State of Punjab . In that case, this Court has emphasised the fact that the mandatory requirement prescribed by s. 374 of the Code of Criminal Procedure shows that in dealing with reference for companyfirmation of death sentence imposed by the Sessions Judge, the High Court has to companysider the entire case for itself before deciding whether the sentence of death should be companyfirmed or number.

precedents.cited_proposition: High Court must independently consider the entire case and evidence before confirming a death sentence under s. 374 CrPC
precedents.cited_holding: the High Court has to consider the entire case for itself before deciding whether the sentence of death should be confirmed or not

precedents.citation: Baladin v. State of Uttar Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: Baladin v. State of Uttar Pradesh . In that case, it was observed by Sinha, J., who spoke for the Court, that it is well-settled that mere presence in an assembly does number make a person, who is present, a member of an unlawful assembly unless it is shown that he had done something or omitted to do something which would make him a member of an unlawful assembly, or unless the case falls under s. 142, I.P.C.

precedents.case_name: Baladin v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Mere presence in an assembly does not make a person a member of an unlawful assembly unless shown to have done something or omitted something making him a member
precedents.cited_holding: mere presence in an assembly does number make a person, who is present, a member of an unlawful assembly unless it is shown that he had done something or omitted to do something which would make him a member of an unlawful assembly

precedents.citation: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab 1954 S.C.R. 145

anchor.surface_text: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab 1954 S.C.R. 145. In that case, what this Court observed was that the power to enhance a sentence from transportation to death should very rarely be exercised and only for the strongest reasons and it was added that it is number enough for the appellate companyrt to say or think that if left to itself it would have awarded the greater penalty because the discretion does number belong to the appellate companyrt but to the trial Judge, and the only ground on which the appellate companyrt can interfere is that the discretion has been improperly exercised.

precedents.case_name: Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Appellate court should rarely enhance sentence to death and only if trial court's discretion improperly exercised
precedents.cited_holding: the power to enhance a sentence from transportation to death should very rarely be exercised and only for the strongest reasons
